para.sentence: In this subsection, and also §§19.20(ii)–19.20(v), the variables of all R -functions satisfy the constraints specified in§19.16(i)unless other conditions are stated. R_{F}\left(x,x,x\right)=x^{-1/2},R_{F}\left(\lambda x,\lambda y,\lambda z\right)=\lambda^{-1/2}R_{F}\left(x,y,z \right),R_{F}\left(x,y,y\right)=R_{C}\left(x,y\right),R_{F}\left(0,y,y\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi y^{-1/2},R_{F}\left(0,0,z\right)=\infty.

The first lemniscate constant is given by \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{1-t^{4}}}=R_{F}\left(0,1,2\right)=\frac{ \left(\Gamma\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\right)^{2}}{4(2\pi)^{1/2}}=1.31102\;87771 \;46059\;90523\;\dots.
Todd (1975) refers to a proof by T. Schneider that this is a transcendental number.
The general lemniscatic case is R_{F}\left(x,a,y\right)=R_{-\frac{1}{4}}\left(\tfrac{3}{4},\tfrac{1}{2};a^{2}, xy\right), if a=\frac{1}{2}(x+y).

R_{G}\left(x,x,x\right)=x^{1/2},R_{G}\left(\lambda x,\lambda y,\lambda z\right)=\lambda^{1/2}R_{G}\left(x,y,z \right),R_{G}\left(0,y,y\right)=\tfrac{1}{4}\pi y^{1/2},R_{G}\left(0,0,z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}z^{1/2}, 2\!R_{G}\left(x,y,y\right)=yR_{C}\left(x,y\right)+\sqrt{x}.

sentence.Math: R_{J}\left(x,x,x,x\right)=x^{-3/2},R_{J}\left(\lambda x,\lambda y,\lambda z,\lambda p\right)=\lambda^{-3/2}R_{J} \left(x,y,z,p\right),R_{J}\left(x,y,z,z\right)=R_{D}\left(x,y,z\right),R_{J}\left(0,0,z,p\right)=\infty,R_{J}\left(x,x,x,p\right)=R_{D}\left(p,p,x\right)=\frac{3}{x-p}\left(R_{C} \left(x,p\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right), if x\neq p, xp\neq 0.

para.sentence: R_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right)\to+\infty, if p\to 0+ or 0-; x,y,z>0.

R_{J}\left(0,y,y,p\right)=\frac{3\pi}{2(y\sqrt{p}+p\sqrt{y})}, if p>0, //// R_{J}\left(0,y,y,-q\right)=\frac{-3\pi}{2\sqrt{y}(y+q)}, if q>0, //// R_{J}\left(x,y,y,p\right)=\frac{3}{p-y}(R_{C}\left(x,y\right)-R_{C}\left(x,p \right)), if p\neq y, //// R_{J}\left(x,y,y,y\right)=R_{D}\left(x,y,y\right).
R_{J}\left(0,y,z,\pm\sqrt{yz}\right)=\pm\frac{3}{2\sqrt{yz}}R_{F}\left(0,y,z \right).

\lim_{p\to 0+}\sqrt{p}R_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)=\frac{3\pi}{2\sqrt{yz}},\lim_{p\to 0-}R_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)={-R_{D}\left(0,y,z\right)-R_{D}\left(0 ,z,y\right)}=\frac{-6}{yz}R_{G}\left(0,y,z\right).
R_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)\sim\frac{3}{2p\sqrt{z}}\ln\left(\frac{16z}{y}\right), if y\to 0+; p (\neq 0) real.
\lim_{p\to\pm\infty}pR_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right)=3\!R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right).
2(p-x)R_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right)=3\!R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right)-3\sqrt{x}R_{C}\left (yz,p^{2}\right), if p=x\pm\sqrt{(y-x)(z-x)}, where x,y,z may be permuted.

When the variables are real and distinct, the various cases of R_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right) are called circular (hyperbolic) cases if (p-x)(p-y)(p-z) is positive (negative), because they typically occur in conjunction with inverse circular (hyperbolic) functions.
Cases encountered in dynamical problems are usually circular; hyperbolic cases include Cauchy principal values.

If x,y,z are permuted so that 0\leq x<y<z , then the Cauchy principal value of R_{J} is given by (q+z)R_{J}\left(x,y,z,-q\right)=(p-z)R_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right)-3\!R_{F}\left(x ,y,z\right)+3\left(\frac{xyz}{xy+pq}\right)^{1/2}R_{C}\left(xy+pq,pq\right), valid when q>0,p=\frac{z(x+y+q)-xy}{z+q}, or p=wy+(1-w)z,w=\frac{z-x}{z+q},0<w<1.
Since x<y<p<z , p is in a hyperbolic region.
In the complete case ( x=0 ) (19.20.14)reduces to (q+z)R_{J}\left(0,y,z,-q\right)=(p-z)R_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)-3\!R_{F}\left(0 ,y,z\right), if p=z(y+q)/(z+q), w=z/(z+q).

R_{D}\left(x,x,x\right)=x^{-3/2},R_{D}\left(\lambda x,\lambda y,\lambda z\right)=\lambda^{-3/2}R_{D}\left(x,y,z \right),R_{D}\left(0,y,y\right)=\tfrac{3}{4}\pi\,y^{-3/2},R_{D}\left(0,0,z\right)=\infty.

The second lemniscate constant is given by \int_{0}^{1}\frac{t^{2}\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{1-t^{4}}}=\tfrac{1}{3}R_{D}\left(0,2 ,1\right)=\frac{\left(\Gamma\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\right)^{2}}{(2\pi)^{1/2}} =0.59907\;01173\;67796\;10371\dots.
Todd (1975) refers to a proof by T. Schneider that this is a transcendental number.
Compare (19.20.2).
The general lemniscatic case is R_{D}\left(x,y,a\right)=R_{-\frac{3}{4}}\left(\tfrac{5}{4},\tfrac{1}{2};a^{2}, xy\right), if a=\tfrac{1}{2}x+\tfrac{1}{2}y.
Define c=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{j}.

Then R_{0}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right)=1,R_{N}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right)=\frac{N!}{{\left(c\right)_{N}}}T_{N}( \mathbf{b},\mathbf{z}), if N=0,1,2,\dots, where T_{N} is defined by (19.19.1).

Also, R_{-c}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{n}z_{j}^{-b_{j}}, R_{-a}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{n}z_{j}^{-b_{j}}R_{-a^{ \prime}}\left(\mathbf{b};\boldsymbol{{z^{-1}}}\right), if a+a^{\prime}=c, \boldsymbol{{z^{-1}}}=(z_{1}^{-1},\dots,z_{n}^{-1}).
